Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), governed by the differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\), where A and B are constant matrices. The system undergoes a Fourier transformation \\( F(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i\\omega t}z(t) dt \\), which modifies its spectral components.

If \\( F(z) \\) is applied to \\( z(t) \\) initially without further transformation, does this affect the time-domain representation of \\( z(t) \\) such that \\( z(t) \\) is altered fundamentally?
Explanation: The Fourier transformation \\( F(z) \\) is a linear and reversible operation affecting only the frequency domain representation of \\( z(t) \\). The time-domain behavior of the system, described by \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\), remains dictated by the differential equations without alteration by the transformation.
